newsitem.title: GERMANY: Koebnick says more EU fiscal convergence needed.
newsitem.headline: Koebnick says more EU fiscal convergence needed.

text.p: Bundesbank council member Hans-Juergen Koebnick said on Wednesday European Union nations had not yet reached an adequate level of convergence on the fiscal criteria for European Economic and Monetary Union.

In the text of a speech to bankers held in the Saar town of Merzig, Koebnick referred specifically to the fact that Germany was heading in the wrong direction on the fiscal criteria to meet the goals laid out in the Maastricht Treaty.
"Germany is heading in the wrong direction to fulfil the deficit criteria," he said.
Germany's 1996 deficit is expected to far exceed a reference value of three percent compared to gross domestic product, the target laid down in the Maastricht Treaty.
But it hopes to rein in the deficit to 2.5 percent in 1997, the key year for achieving the Maastricht goals.

Referring to the fact that Germany had failed to meet this target in recent years, Koebnick said, "whoever argues for a generous interpretation of the fiscal criteria calls into question the guiding lines and basic tenets of German fiscal policy over the last few decades."

He added that EMU ought to be able to kick off with sufficient members even without bending the rules on the fiscal criteria. "Current budget drafts among EU nations still allow a possible meeting of the Treaty criteria in spirit and letter.
He added, "that means the currency union begins on Jan. 1, 1999, it will begin with six to eight nations including France and Germany."
